THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ricky Hatcher, Respondent,
				v.
				Edward D. Jones
      & Co., L.P. and David C. Freeman, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge 
Opinion No.Â Â  4431
Heard May 8, 2008 â€“ Filed August 14, 2008
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED
  IN PART, and REMANDED


	
		
			
				E. Linwood Gunn, IV, of Canton and Sylvia Germaine Eaves, of Marietta, for Appellants.
				Michael F. Mullinax, of Anderson, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.: Â The issue presented here is whether a broadly-worded
  arbitration clause contained in an agreement for investment services should be
  applied to a lawsuit alleging the clientâ€™s funds were transferred
  electronically to a third party without his authorization or consent.Â  We hold
  the claims relating to breach of the underlying agreement should be arbitrated
  but the claims for negligence and a violation of the South Carolina Unfair
  Trade Practices Act (SCUTPA) are not subject to arbitration.Â  Accordingly, we
  affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
Ricky
  Hatcher opened a Roth Individual Retirement Account with Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. (Edward Jones) in May of 2004.Â  This account was
  managed by David Freeman, an agent for Edward Jones.Â  At the beginning of his
  relationship with Edward Jones, Hatcher signed an authorized adoption agreement
  which contained an arbitration clause stating:Â  â€œany controversy arising out of
  or relating to any of my accounts or transactions with you, your officers,
  directors, agents, and/or employees for me, to this agreement, or to the breach
  thereof . . . from the inception of such account shall be settled by
  arbitration.â€Â  
According
  to Hatcherâ€™s complaint, he deposited $113,584.68 with Edward Jones and Freeman
  (collectively Appellants) on or about May 1, 2004.Â  Subsequently, the majority
  of those funds were withdrawn without his permission and deposited in an
  account of Hatcherâ€™s, and thereafter were withdrawn by a third person, who is
  now incarcerated as a result of her actions.Â  Â 
Â Hatcher
  brought this action against Appellants alleging the following causes of
  action:Â  breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent
  act, negligence, breach of fiduciary duty, and violation of SCUTPA.Â Â Â  Hatcher
  alleged Appellants allowed his money to be withdrawn and wired to bank accounts
  without his knowledge.
Appellants answered
  Hatcherâ€™s complaint asserting numerous defenses, including that Hatcherâ€™s
  claims were subject to a binding arbitration provision.Â  Thereafter, Appellants
  filed a motion to compel arbitration and a hearing was held.Â  The circuit court
  denied the motion to compel arbitration, finding the â€œtheft and conversionâ€ of
  Hatcherâ€™s money was completely independent of the contract and could be
  maintained without reference to the contract.Â  Moreover, the circuit court
  found the removal of Hatcherâ€™s money arose out of the unauthorized transfer of
  funds from his account, and that Hatcher did not sign a contract authorizing electronic
  funds transfer.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe determination of whether a claim is subject to
  arbitration is subject to de novo review.â€Â  Wellman, Inc. v. Square D Co.,
  366 S.C. 61, 67, 620 S.E.2d 86, 89 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  However, a circuit courtâ€™s
  factual findings will not be reversed on appeal if any evidence reasonably
  supports the findings.Â  Thornton v. Trident Med. Ctr., L.L.C.,
  357 S.C. 91, 94, 592 S.E.2d 50, 51 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANAYLSIS
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in denying
  their motion to compel arbitration because the arbitration agreement signed by
  Hatcher required that any controversy arising out of and/or relating to any
  account or transaction be submitted to arbitration.Â  We agree with Appellants
  that the circuit court erred in failing to find Hatcherâ€™s claims for breach of
  contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, and breach of
  fiduciary duty are subject to arbitration.Â  However, we find the circuit court
  correctly held Hatcherâ€™s claims for negligence and violation of SCUTPA are not
  subject to arbitration.
Both
  state and federal policy favor the arbitration of disputes.Â  Zabinski v.
    Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001); see also Chassereau v. Global Sun Pools, Inc., 373 S.C. 168, 171, 644
  S.E.2d 718, 720 (2007).Â  Unless a court can say with positive assurance that
  the arbitration clause is not susceptible to any interpretation that covers the
  dispute, arbitration should ordinarily be ordered.Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C.
  at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118-19.Â  However, arbitration is a matter of contract,
  and a party cannot be required to arbitrate any dispute that he has not agreed
  to arbitrate.Â  Id. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  Accordingly, courts generally
  hold broadly-worded arbitration agreements apply to disputes in which a
  â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ exists between the asserted claims and the contract
  containing the agreement to arbitrate.Â  Id. at 598, 553 S.E.2d at 119 (citing Long v. Silver, 248 F.3d 309 (4th Cir. 2001)).
Appellants
  argue all of the claims asserted by Hatcher relate to the investment account that
  he set up with Edwards Jones, and, therefore, arbitration is warranted.Â  We
  agree as to some of the claims filed by Hatcher but disagree as to others.
In Aiken
  v. World Finance Corp. of S.C., 373 S.C. 144, 644 S.E.2d 705 (2007), our
  supreme court refused to apply a broadly-worded arbitration clause to the theft
  of Aikenâ€™s personal information by World Finance employees.Â  In holding there was
  not such a significant relationship between Aikenâ€™s contracts with World
  Finance and the tortious acts of its employees, the court specifically rejected
  World Financeâ€™s argument, similar to the one asserted by Appellants here, that
  without the underlying agreement, there could have been no theft giving rise to
  Aikenâ€™s claims.Â  The supreme court stated: 

	Applying
  what amounts to be a â€œbut-forâ€ causation standard essentially includes every
  dispute imaginable between the parties, which greatly oversimplifies the
  partiesâ€™ agreement to arbitrate claims between them.Â  Such a result is
  illogical and unconscionable. . . . â€œThe mere fact that the dispute would not
  have arisen but for the existence of the contract and consequent relationship
  between the parties is insufficient by itself to transform a dispute into one
  â€˜arising out of or relating toâ€™ the underlying agreement.â€ 

Id. at 150, 644 S.E.2d at 708 (quoting Seifert v. U.S.
  Home Corp., 750 So. 2d 633, 638 (Fla. 1999)).
The
  supreme court held the theft of Aikenâ€™s personal information by World Finance was
  outrageous conduct that could not possibly have been foreseen when Aiken agreed
  to do business with World Finance.Â  Consequently, the court held Aikenâ€™s claims
  for outrage and emotional distress, negligence, negligent hiring/supervision,
  and unfair trade practices were not subject to arbitration.Â  
However,
  the Aiken court instructed that its opinion should not be interpreted as
  excluding all intentional torts from the scope of arbitration.Â  For example, a
  claim which essentially alleges a breach of the underlying contract such as
  breach of fiduciary duty or misappropriation of trade secrets would be within
  the contemplation of the parties in agreeing to arbitrate.Â  Id. at 152,
  644 S.E.2d at 709.Â Â Â Â  
Applying
  the courtâ€™s analysis in Aiken to the claims advanced by Hatcher
  in this case, we hold the claims for breach of contract, breach of contract
  accompanied by a fraudulent act, and breach of fiduciary duty allege a breach
  of the underlying contract, and are therefore subject to the partiesâ€™ agreement
  to arbitrate.Â  However, Hatcher also sued for negligence and violation of
  SCUTPA.Â  As in Aiken, although these claims are factually related to the
  performance of the contract, each action is legally distinct from the
  contractual relationship between the parties, and therefore, was not within the
  contemplation of the partiesâ€™ agreement to arbitrate.[1]Â 
  Just as the supreme court held in Aiken, we find that to interpret the
  arbitration provision contained in Hatcherâ€™s contract with Edward Jones to
  apply to alleged action completely outside the expectations of the parties at
  the time the contract was entered would be inconsistent with the goal favoring
  arbitration as an effective means for resolving disputes. 
Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED IN PART,
  REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
SHORT, J., and KONDUROS, J., concur.Â  

[1] We recognize our court recently held a SCUTPA claim
  was subject to arbitration when the underlying agreement between the parties
  was for the sale of a vehicle, and plaintiff alleged he received a vehicle
  different from the one he thought he was purchasing. Â Partain v. Upstate
    Auto. Group, Op. No. 4373 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed April 23, 2008) (Shearouse
  Adv. Sh. No. 16 at 69).Â  The significant relationship we found existed between
  Partainâ€™s claim and the underlying agreement is not extant here, where the
  underlying agreement is for the investment of Hatcherâ€™s monies, and the SCUTPA
  claim is based on the wrongful electronic transfer of Hatcherâ€™s funds at the
  direction of a third party and without Hatcherâ€™s prior consent.Â

description: This workers' compensation case involves the issues of whether an employee's injuries sustained in a fall were causally related to a previous work-related injury and whether the order of the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workers' Compensation Commission made sufficient findings of fact to support its determination that the injuries were not compensable.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Albertha
          Sanders, Employee, Respondent,
        v.
        Wal-Mart
          Stores, Inc., Employer, and American Home Assurance, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
  Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Opinion No. 4432 
  Submitted January 2, 2008 â€“ Filed August
  19, 2008

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Johnnie W. Baxley, III, of Mt. Pleasant; for Appellants.
        Margie Bright Matthews, of Walterboro; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J. :Â  In
  this workersâ€™ compensation action, Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. appeals from an order
  of the circuit court reversing the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s finding that Albertha Sandersâ€™ knee injuries
  were not work-related. Â We reverse.[1]
FACTS
On June 14, 2000, Albertha Sanders
  suffered an injury to her knee descending from a ladder while working at
  Wal-Mart.Â  Wal-Mart acknowledged the injuries arising from this accident were
  compensable and provided medical treatment.Â  
After
  receiving treatment for her injuries by several physicians, Sanders was
  diagnosed with chondromalacia patella, the softening and degeneration of the
  tissue underneath the kneecap.Â  Sanders was released from treatment on February
  15, 2001.Â  At the time of her release, Sanders had returned to work without
  restrictions, other than to avoid stooping, kneeling, and squatting whenever
  possible.Â  
In
  September of 2002, Sanders fell down stairs in her home and suffered an injury
  to her knee as a result. Following this incident, Sanders received medical care
  for her knee from Dr. Jeffrey Holman.Â  Sanders filed this claim seeking
  workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Wal-Mart contested liability for this injury,
  asserting Sandersâ€™ September of 2002 fall in the home was an intervening act
  unrelated to her previous work-related injury and was not compensable.Â Â  
The single commissioner found Sandersâ€™ knee injuries were causally
  related to the original injury in June of 2000 and awarded Sanders temporary
  total disability benefits and payment of her medical expenses.Â  
Wal-Mart appealed the findings of the single commissioner to the
  Appellate Panel.Â  The Appellate Panel found the injuries in question were not
  causally related to her work-related incident and reversed the order of the
  single commissioner.Â  
Following the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision, Sanders appealed to the
  circuit court.Â  The circuit court reversed and remanded the case to the
  Appellate Panel for reinstatement of the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  This appeal
  followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  Administrative Procedures Act establishes our standard of review of decisions
  by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission. Accordingly, this court can reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s
  decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced
  because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000);
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a
  mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such
  evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds
  to reach the conclusion the [Appellate Panel] reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341
  S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent
  conclusions does not prevent the Appellate Panelâ€™s conclusions from being
  supported by substantial evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of
  Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999).
The
  Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s
  findings of fact.Â  Ross v. American Red Cross,  298 S.C. 490, 492,
  381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and
  the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate Panel. Â Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Independent Intervening Cause
Wal-Mart
  argues the circuit court erred in reversing the order of the Appellate Panel.Â 
  Specifically, Wal-Mart argues there was substantial evidence supporting the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that Sandersâ€™ injuries from her September of 2002
  fall were not causally related to her work-related accident.Â  We agree.Â  
It
  is not disputed that Sandersâ€™ injuries from the initial fall at work are
  compensable.Â  Indeed, Wal-Mart paid workersâ€™ compensation benefits and medical
  expenses related to this incident.Â  The sole issue before the Appellate Panel
  was whether Sandersâ€™ injuries arising out of her September of 2002 fall are
  compensable.Â  As the Appellate Panel correctly noted, every natural consequence
  which flows from a compensable injury,
  unless the result of an independent intervening cause sufficient to break the
  chain of causation, is compensable.Â  Whitfield v. Daniel Constr. Co.,
  226 S.C. 37, 40-41, 83 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1954).Â  The key issue for the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s determination was whether the September of 2002 fall was an
  â€œindependent intervening cause.â€ 
In
  reversing the Appellate Panel, the circuit court held there was not sufficient
  evidence to support the Panelâ€™s conclusion because â€œthere is no finding of fact
  by the [Appellate Panel] that the Claimantâ€™s subsequent fall was an independent
  cause.â€Â  Wal-Mart, however, argues the Appellate Panel did find Sandersâ€™
  September of 2002 fall was independent of her work-related injury.Â  
Under
  the substantial evidence standard, an appellate court looks for all evidence
  which â€œwould allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the
  administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its
  action.â€Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d
  304, 306 (1981) (emphasis added). Â However, â€œif a material fact is contested,
  the [Appellate Panel] must make a specific, express
  finding on it.â€Â  Aristizabal v. I. J. Woodside-Division of Dan River, Inc.,
  268 S.C. 366, 370-71, 234 S.E.2d 21, 23 (1977).Â  The findings of fact of the
  Appellate Panel must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing court to
  determine (1) whether the law has
  been properly applied to those findings and (2) whether the findings are
  supported by the evidence. Â Brayboy v. Clark Heating Co., Inc., 306 S.C.
  56, 58-59, 409 S.E.2d 767, 768 (1991). 
In
  the present case, we must determine whether the Appellate Panel properly
  applied the standard articulated in Whitfield.Â  The sole issue before
  the Appellate Panel was whether Sandersâ€™ September of 2002 fall was causally
  related to the initial work-related accident.Â  The Appellate Panel recognized
  the appropriate standard to be applied by citing and relying upon the holding
  of Whitfield, stating, â€œEvery natural consequence which flows from a
  compensable injury, unless the result of an independent intervening cause
  sufficient to break the chain of causation, is compensable.â€Â  The Appellate
  Panel found:Â  â€œClaimant sustained an intervening accident in September 2002.â€Â 
  It noted there was no evidence that Sandersâ€™ knee condition caused her to fall
  at home.Â  In addition, it found â€œAll of her injuries from the initial injury of
  June 14, 2000 had resolved, [Sanders] had returned to work with no
  restrictions, and she was not given a permanency rating.Â  She did not seek
  additional medical treatment for twenty (20) months.â€Â  
Looking
  at the language of the Appellate Panelâ€™s Order, we hold the findings
  sufficiently indicate the Appellate Panel found the September of 2002 fall was
  an â€œindependent intervening cause sufficient to break the chain of causationâ€
  and thus the findings support the Appellate Panelâ€™s determination to deny
  Sandersâ€™ claims for benefits.Â  Therefore, the circuit court erred in reversing
  the Appellate Panelâ€™s order for lack of such findings.Â Â Â  
Having
  established the Appellate Panel found Sandersâ€™ September of 2002 fall was an
  independent intervening cause, we now turn to whether this finding is supported
  by substantial evidence.
At
  the December 16, 2004 hearing, Sanders testified she was released from care for
  the injuries immediately following her initial fall on February 15, 2001, and
  from that time she did not seek care for her knee until after she fell in her
  home in September of 2002.Â  Furthermore, in her November 7, 2002 deposition she
  testified she was injured a week before she saw Dr. Holman when her knee â€œgave
  outâ€ while she was coming down her steps at home, and prior to this occasion,
  her knee had never given out before.Â  Sandersâ€™ testimony shows a definite gap
  in time from the initial work-related injuries and the September of 2002 fall
  where she did not need medical treatment for her knee and could work full duty
  without restrictions.Â  Therefore, her testimony supports the finding the
  September of 2002 fall was an independent intervening cause. 
In
  addition to Sandersâ€™ testimony, the expert testimony of Sandersâ€™ treating
  physician, Dr. Holman, supports the conclusion the September of 2002 fall was
  an independent intervening cause.Â  Dr. Holman testified Sanders was referred to
  him by her family physician, and his first visit with her occurred on October
  7, 2002.Â  Dr. Holman stated Sanders did not inform him of her subsequent fall
  in the home, which occurred approximately one week before this visit, or that
  following her initial work-related fall she returned to work full duty for
  approximately twenty months. Â Upon hearing Sandersâ€™ testimony regarding these
  facts in her deposition, Dr. Holman testified the knee problems he was treating
  her for were related to the September of 2002 fall rather than her initial fall
  at work.Â  He explained the two similar incidents might suggest that the
  mechanism of the two falls was the same, so â€œeither she had a knee problem
  before she fell at Wal-Mart or that she just slipped and fell on two
  occasions.â€Â  Because of these two similar incidents, Dr. Holman testified he
  could not state â€œwith a degree of medical certainty that her chondromalacia was
  responsible for the missed step a week prior to my visit.â€Â  
Based
  on this evidence from the record, we hold there was substantial evidence to
  support the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding the September of 2002 fall was an
  independent intervening cause and thus Sandersâ€™ injuries arising from the fall
  were not compensable.Â  Accordingly, we find the circuit court erred in
  reversing the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision.
II. Scrivenerâ€™s Error 
Wal-Mart
  argues the circuit court erred in holding the Appellate Panelâ€™s citation of
  South Carolina Code Section 42-9-60 constituted reversible error.Â  We agree.Â  
Section 42-9-60
  provides: Â â€œNo compensation shall be
  payable if the injury or death was occasioned by the intoxication of the
  employee or by the wilful intention of the employee to injure or kill himself
  or another.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-60 (Supp.
  2007).Â  As the circuit court correctly
  noted, there was no evidence showing Sanders was under the influence of
  intoxication or possessed the intent to injure herself and the Appellate Panel
  made no findings concerning such evidence.Â  
Wal-Mart
  argues the Appellate Panelâ€™s citation of Section 42-9-60 was merely a
  scrivenerâ€™s error, and instead the Panel intended to cite South Carolina Code
  Section 42-15-60 (Supp. 2007), which
  discusses medical benefits.Â  Indeed, the Appellate Panel cited to Section
  42-9-60 when concluding Wal-Mart was only responsible for the medical care
  Sanders received between June 14, 2000 and February 15, 2001.Â  
We
  agree with Wal-Mart and hold the Appellate Panelâ€™s use of Section 42-9-60 was a
  scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  â€œAn error not shown to be prejudicial does not constitute
  grounds for reversal.â€ Â JKT Co. v. Hardwick, 274 S.C. 413, 419, 265
  S.E.2d 510, 513 (1980).Â  In the present case, the Appellate Panelâ€™s error in
  citing Section 42-9-60 is not prejudicial.Â  Therefore, the circuit court erred
  in reversing the Appellate Panel on these grounds.Â 
III. Inappropriate Relief
In
  its last argument, Wal-Mart asserts the circuit court erred in granting relief
  that exceeds its authority.Â  As we have reversed the circuit courtâ€™s order for
  the above-stated reasons, we need not address this issue.Â  Â Â Â Â 

CONCLUSION
For the foregoing
  reasons, the order of the circuit court is
REVERSED.
PIEPER, J., and
  CURETON, A.J., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

				v.
				Paragon Builders, and Kenneth W. Rose, Defendants, 
				of whom Paragon Builders is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lancaster County
Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4433
Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed August 27,

  Appellant.

THOMAS, J.: Paragon
  Builders appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of its motion to compel arbitration
  or dismiss the complaint of New Hope Missionary Baptist Church.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
Paragon
  Builders, L.L.C. of Orangeburg, South Carolina, signed a contract with New Hope Missionary Baptist Church (Church) on or between September 30 and October 3, 2004.
  Â The two-page Contract was entitled a â€œConstruction Management Agreementâ€
  wherein Paragon Builders avowed to help bring the construction of a new church
  facility â€œonlineâ€ by working as â€œthe chief construction advisor.â€ Â Under the
  Contract, Paragon Builders pledged to work with the Churchâ€™s architect in North Carolina, appointed church leaders, state and local building inspectors, local city
  and county governments, utilities, bankers and others associated with the
  project.

  clause stating, â€œ[a]ll disputes hereunder shall be resolved by binding
  arbitration in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration
  Association.â€ Â The Contract also provided that the Church would pay Paragon
  Builders twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) but that â€œif for any reason

  the contractorâ€ and the Church â€œwill not receive any funds back.â€ Â Payment of
  the entire $25,000 amount was due at the signing of the Contract. 
The
  Contract was signed by Kenny W. Rose and Emoray R. Waiters, allegedly on behalf
  of the Church.[2] Â At some point, a payment of twenty-five thousand dollars was made from Church
  funds to Paragon Builders.Â  Thereafter, the Church filed a declaratory judgment
  action asking the court to determine the existence, validity, and
  enforceability of the Contract. Â 
The
  Churchâ€™s complaint raised numerous issues regarding the validity of the
  Contract, including the absence of any meeting of the minds, Paragon Buildersâ€™
  lack of consideration, and the ambiguity of the Contract with regard to Paragon
  Buildersâ€™ obligations.Â  The Church asserted the $25,000 payment and ensuing
  deposit were not authorized by the Church but was â€œthe misguided action of the
  church financial secretary acting ex officio.â€ The complaint
  prayed for a refund of the $25,000 payment. Â 
The
  complaint contended neither Rose[3] nor Waiters was a â€œtrustee[] of the church nor were they authorized by the
  church to enter into any such contract.â€ Â Waitersâ€™ signature was also claimed
  to be a forgery. Â The Church contended the signatures on a blank page attached
  to the Contract were â€œsimply a list of people who attended a meeting regarding
  the contractâ€ and did not constitute a signature page which was part of the
  Contract. Â The Church asserted the Contract â€œwas not approved by any vote of
  the church or any authorized committee or organization of the churchâ€ and as
  such does not bind the Church. Â 
Paragon
  Builders timely answered denying the Church was entitled to a declaratory
  judgment or a refund. Â The Answer also pled an affirmative defense pursuant to
  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, that the Church failed to state a claim upon which relief
  can be granted, and that the Churchâ€™s claims were subject to arbitration under
  the Contract.

On
  July 3, 2006, Paragon Builders filed a Motion to Compel Arbitration and Dismiss
  or Stay the Complaint. Â The motion was heard on October 9, 2006, and
  subsequently denied. Â The trial court held, â€œ[u]nder the Federal Arbitration
  Act and S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-10, before arbitration may be compelled, there
  must be a determination that there was an agreement between the parties,â€ and
  this was the very issue the Church contested. Â The trial court further held,
  â€œuntil there is a determination by the Court as to whether or not the parties
  had an agreement, arbitration cannot be compelled.â€ Â Paragon Builders now
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Unless the parties otherwise provide, the question of the
  arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination. Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â 
  Appeal from the denial of a motion to compel arbitration is subject to de novo
  review. Chassereau v. Global Sun Pools, Inc., 373 S.C. 168, 171, 644
  S.E.2d 718, 720 (2007). Â Nevertheless, a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings will
  not be reversed on appeal if any evidence reasonably supports the findings. Thornton v. Trident Med. Ctr., L.L.C., 357 S.C. 91, 94, 592 S.E.2d 50, 51 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Paragon
  Builders claims the trial court erred in denying its Motion to Compel
  Arbitration brought pursuant to Section 15-48-20(a) of the South Carolina Code
  (2005).Â  Specifically, Paragon Builders asserts the Contractâ€™s arbitration
  clause requires disputes arising out of the Contract be resolved through
  arbitration.Â  Pursuant to Prima Paint Corp. v. Flood & Conklin Mfg. Co.,
  388 U.S. 395 (1967), and The Housing Authority of City of Columbia v.
    Cornerstone Housing, L.L.C., 356 S.C. 328, 588 S.E.2d 617 (Ct. App. 2003), we
  find the trial court erred in denying Paragon Buildersâ€™ Motion to Compel
  Arbitration since the Church failed to specifically challenge the arbitration
  agreement.
Section
  15-48-10(a) of the South Carolina Code (2005) states, â€œ[a] written agreement to submit any existing controversy to arbitration
  or a provision in a written contract to submit to arbitration any controversy
  thereafter arising between the parties is valid, enforceable and irrevocable,
  save upon such grounds as exist at law or in equity for the revocation of any
  contract.â€Â  The Legislature also provided that:

	On application of a party showing an [arbitration] agreement
  described in Â§ 15-48-10,
  and the opposing partyâ€™s refusal to arbitrate, the court shall order the
  parties to proceed with arbitration, but if the opposing party denies the
  existence of the agreement to arbitrate, the court shall proceed summarily to
  the determination of the issue so raised and shall order arbitration if found
  for the moving party, otherwise, the application shall be denied.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-20(a)
  (2005).Â  An order denying a motion to compel arbitration[4] made under Section 15-48-20 is immediately appealable. S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-48-200(a)(1) (2005); Towles v. United HealthCare Corp., 338 S.C. 29,
  35, 524 S.E.2d 839, 842-43 (Ct. App. 1999).
As a
  preliminary note, we find the trial court properly determined the Federal
  Arbitration Act (â€œFAAâ€) applies to the arbitration agreement in this matter
  since the parties did not contract to the contrary and the arbitration
  agreement pertains to a transaction involving interstate commerce due to the
  nature of the construction project, Paragon Buildersâ€™ position as chief
  construction advisor, and Paragon Buildersâ€™ affidavit swearing the project will
  involve businesses and supplies from outside South Carolina. Munoz v. Green
    Tree Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 538-39, 542 S.E.2d 360, 363 (2001) (â€œUnless
  the parties have contracted to the contrary, the FAA applies in federal or
  state courts to any arbitration agreement regarding a transaction that in fact
  involves interstate commerce, regardless of whether or not the parties
  contemplated an interstate transaction.â€); Episcopal Hous. Corp. v. Federal
    Ins. Co., 269 S.C. 631, 640, 239 S.E.2d 647, 652 (1977) (â€œIt would be
  virtually impossible to construct an eighteen (18) story apartment building
  between 1971 and 1973 with materials, equipment and supplies all produced and
  manufactured solely within the State of South Carolina.â€); Blanton v.
    Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 540-41, 570 S.E.2d 565, 568-69 (Ct. App. 2002)
  (holding Blantonâ€™s affidavit asserting the contract affected interstate
  commerce, Stathosâ€™s failure to dispute the affidavit, and the nature of the construction
  project were sufficient to uphold the decision of the circuit court that the
  contract evinces a transaction involving interstate commerce); Towles, 338
  S.C. at 36, 524 S.E.2d at 843 (â€œBecause interstate commerce is involved, the
  FAA applies and displaces South Carolinaâ€™s Uniform Arbitration Act.â€) (citing Soil
    Remediation Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 323 S.C. 454, 459-60, 476 S.E.2d
  149, 152 (1996)).
Arbitration
  is a matter of contract and a party cannot be required to submit to arbitration
  any dispute which he has not agreed to submit. Zabinski v. Bright Acres
    Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001); Aiken v. World
      Fin. Corp. of S.C., 373 S.C. 144, 149, 644 S.E.2d 705, 708 (2007); Chassereau
        v. Global Sun Pools, Inc., 373 S.C. 168, 171-72, 644 S.E.2d 718, 720
  (2007).Â  Since the Church contends a valid, enforceable contract does not
  exist, this is no doubt one reason why the trial court denied Paragon Buildersâ€™
  Motion to Compel Arbitration until the court could determine whether or not the
  parties had an agreement.Â  However, further examination of case law from the
  United States Supreme Court and the South Carolina Supreme Court yields the
  surprising result that when a party argues fraud in the inducement of an entire
  contract, but not the arbitration agreement itself, arbitration cannot be
  avoided. Prima Paint, 388 U.S. 395; S.C. Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Great
    Western Coal, Inc., 312 S.C. 559, 437 S.E.2d 22 (1993); Jackson Mills,
      Inc. v. BT Capital Corp., 312 S.C. 400, 440 S.E.2d 877 (1994); Cornerstone
        Hous., 356 S.C. 328, 588 S.E.2d 617 (Ct. App. 2003).
In Prima
  Paint, 388 U.S. at 403-04, the United States Supreme Court held that
  general allegations of fraud in the inducement of a contract are insufficient
  to prevent the invocation of a contractâ€™s arbitration clause.Â  The court
  referenced Section 4[5] of the FAA and concluded that with respect to cases evidencing transactions in
  commerce:

	if the
  claim is fraud in the inducement[6] of the arbitration clause itself â€“ an issue which goes to the â€˜makingâ€™ of the
  agreement to arbitrate â€“ the federal court may proceed to adjudicate it . . . [b]ut
  the statutory language does not permit the federal court to consider claims of
  fraud in the inducement of the contract generally. 

388 U.S. at 403-04.Â  In Great Western Coal, Inc., 312 S.C. at 562-63, 437 S.E.2d at 24 (emphasis
  added), the South Carolina Supreme Court explained how the rule of Prima
    Paint should be applied by our courts:

	We join the jurisdictions which have rejected limiting the holding
  in Prima Paint. Â We hold a party cannot avoid arbitration through
  rescission of the entire contract when there
  is no independent challenge to the arbitration clause. Fraud as a
  defense to an arbitration clause must be fraud specifically as to the
  arbitration clause and not the contract generally.

A party may
  allege the arbitration agreement was never entered into and â€œunder such
  circumstances, a challenge to the existence of the arbitration agreement itself
  becomes a matter to be â€˜forthwith and summarily triedâ€™ by the Court.â€ Jackson
    Mills, 312 S.C. at 404, 440 S.E.2d at 879 (citations omitted).
In its complaint, at the hearing, and in its brief to this court,
  the Church does not specifically allege the arbitration clause in the Contract
  is invalid, unenforceable, or does not exist. Â Instead, the Church argues it
  has numerous grounds on which the Contract is invalid and that â€œthe
  Contract simply does not exist as a Contractâ€ in part because of Roseâ€™s
  inability to bind the Church. 
We acknowledge the United States Supreme Court has identified
  certain limited circumstances in which â€œcourts assume that the parties intended
  courts, not arbitrators, to decide a particular arbitration-related matter (in
  the absence of â€˜clear and unmistakableâ€™ evidence to the contrary).â€ Green
    Tree Fin. Corp. v. Bazzle, 539 U.S. 444, 452 (2003).Â  These â€œgateway
  mattersâ€ include whether the parties have a valid arbitration agreement or
  whether a binding arbitration clause applies to a certain type of controversy. Id.Â  However, in the present case we are not confronted with the question of whether
  an arbitration agreement encompasses a certain dispute[7] or whether the arbitration agreement
  is invalid. Instead, we have been presented with the question of whether arbitration
  should be compelled when a contractâ€™s validity has been challenged.
Common sense implies that if a party challenged the validity of a
  contract which contained an arbitration clause, the validity of the arbitration
  clause is also challenged.Â  The courts have found otherwise.Â  â€œArbitration clauses
  are separable[8] from the contracts in which they are imbedded.â€ Jackson Mills, 312 S.C.
  at 403, 440 S.E.2d at 879 (citing Prima Paint, 388 U.S. at 402).Â  An arbitration clauseâ€™s validity is distinct from the substantive validity
  of the contract as a whole. Cornerstone Hous., 356 S.C. at 338, 588
  S.E.2d at 622 (citing Munoz, 343 S.C. at 540, 542 S.E.2d at 364). â€œEven
  if the overall contract is unenforceable, the arbitration provision is not
  unenforceable unless the reason the overall contract is unenforceable
  specifically relates to the arbitration provision.â€ Cornerstone Hous.,
  356 S.C. at 340, 588 S.E.2d at 623.Â  
The policies of the United States and this State favor arbitration
  of disputes. Stokes v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 610-11,
  571 S.E.2d 711, 713-14 (Ct.
  App. 2002); Tritech Elec.,
    Inc. v. Frank M. Hall & Co., 343 S.C. 396, 399, 540 S.E.2d 864, 865 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation
  omitted); Towles, 338 S.C. at 37, 524 S.E.2d at 844.Â  â€œThe FAA was designed â€˜to overrule the judiciaryâ€™s long-standing
  refusal to enforce agreements to arbitrate.â€™â€ Volt Info. Sciences, Inc. v. Bd.
    of Trustees of Leland Stanford Junior Univ., 489 U.S. 468, 478 (1989) (citation
  omitted).Â  The Churchâ€™s argument that the entire Contract is invalid can be
  considered at the arbitration itself. Cornerstone Hous., 356 S.C. at
  340, 588 S.E.2d at 623; see Bazzle, 539 U.S. 444, 453 (noting arbitrators are well suited to address issues such as contract
  interpretation and arbitration procedures).
We further acknowledge that â€œwhere there has been no agreement to
  arbitrate, a party cannot be forced into compulsory arbitration.â€ Hilton
    Head Resort Four Seasons Ctr. Horizontal Prop. Regime Council v. Resort Inv. Corp.,
  311 S.C. 394, 397-98, 429 S.E.2d 459, 462 (Ct. App. 1993) (citation omitted).Â  Again,
  precedent forces a distinction to be drawn between disputes in which a party
  challenges the arbitration agreement itself and disputes in which only the
  overall contract is challenged.Â  See Simpson v. MSA of Myrtle Beach,
    Inc., 373 S.C. 14, 23-24, 644 S.E.2d 663, 668 (2007) (holding the trial
  court was the proper forum for determining the enforceability of the
  arbitration clause in the contract because â€œ[a]lthough the clause specifically
  stated that arbitration applied to issues involving â€˜the validity and scope of
  this contract,â€™ Simpson challenged the validity of the arbitration provision on
  grounds of unconscionability, bringing into question whether an arbitration
  agreement even existed in the first placeâ€); Cornerstone Hous., 356 S.C.
  at 338-42, 588 S.E.2d at 622-24 (holding because a party did not directly
  challenge the arbitration agreement in either of the two contracts, the
  legality and enforceability of the contracts is an issue for the arbitrator to
  decide).Â  Indeed, even Section 15-48-20(a) of the South Carolina Code (2005)
  notes when a party presents a court with an arbitration agreement and the
  opposing partyâ€™s refusal to arbitrate, the court shall order the parties to
  proceed with arbitration unless â€œthe opposing party denies the existence of the agreement to arbitrate.â€ S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 15-48-20(a) (2005) (emphasis added).Â  Unlike
  the cases argued by the Church, the matter presently before us does not raise
  the issue of whether the arbitration clause in Article 2 of the Contract is
  invalid.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
REVERSED. 
WILLIAMS,
  J., concurs. 
PIEPER,
  J., dissents in a separate opinion.
PIEPER, J., dissenting:
I respectfully
  dissent.Â  In my opinion, this case involves more than a situation where a party
  alleges fraud in the inducement of just the contract itself, as opposed to
  challenging the arbitration provision of the contract.Â  I believe the Church
  has raised a colorable claim that there was no arbitration agreement by
  alleging the signer of the agreement had neither the authority to agree to the
  contract itself, nor the authority to agree to the arbitration provision.
I fully support the
  policy in favor of arbitration and will not resort to citation of the law in
  this regard.Â  I believe the majority opinion fully recounts the applicable
  law.Â  However, the majority notes that where there has been no agreement to
  arbitrate, a party cannot be forced to do so.Â  I believe further clarification
  of the law in this area is necessary.Â  Based on the facts of this case, I find
  it very problematic that a person, without authority, may set out to not only
  bind another to a contract, but also to arbitration without the right to do so,
  and without a preliminary court determination on the issue of the authority to
  bind (i.e. the existence of the agreement to arbitrate).Â  Under the facts
  herein, I respectfully believe this case falls within that type of â€œgateway
  matterâ€ ripe for a judicial determination as to the existence of the agreement
  to arbitrate.Â  See Simpson v. MSA of Myrtle Beach, Inc., 373 S.C.
  14, 22, 644 S.E.2d 663, 667 (2007) (stating where one party denies the
  existence of an arbitration agreement raised by an opposing party, a court must
  immediately determine whether the agreement exists in the first place); see
    also 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 4 (2008) (wherein the Federal Arbitration Act directs the
  court to summarily determine the existence of the arbitration agreement if it
  is at issue); accord S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-20(a) (2005).Â  
Moreover, the circuit
  court did not rule that arbitration may not eventually result; instead, the
  court concluded that a preliminary and threshold determination must be made
  about the existence of an agreement to arbitrate.Â  Once that threshold
  determination is made, I do not read the courtâ€™s order as precluding
  arbitration if the issue as to the authority to enter the agreement to
  arbitrate is determined adversely to the Church.Â  Therefore, I agree with the
  assertion by the Church in its brief that the appeal is premature.
Accordingly, I
  would affirm.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In the Record on Appeal, a single page bearing
  twenty-eight signatures has been attached to the Contract. Â The page bears no
  identifying marks or explanation regarding the identity of the twenty-eight
signatories or why twenty-eight individuals signed the blank sheet of paper. 
[3] The Church further explained that although Rose was
  the pastor when the Contract was signed, there was an ongoing dispute with Rose
  at that time, and â€œninety-nine percent of the activity that related to this
  Contract took place directly between the pastor and the contractor,â€ without
any information being relayed to the Church. 
[4] This court also recently dealt with a motion to
  compel arbitration in Partain v. Upstate Automotive Group, Op. No. 4373
(S.C. Ct. App. filed April 23, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 16 at 69).
[5] Section 4 provides in part, â€œThe court shall hear the
  parties, and upon being satisfied that the making of the agreement for
  arbitration or the failure to comply therewith is not in issue, the court shall
  make an order directing the parties to proceed to arbitration in accordance with
  the terms of the agreement . . . [i]f the making of the arbitration agreement
  or the failure, neglect, or refusal to perform the same be in issue, the court
shall proceed summarily to the trial thereof.â€ 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 4 (2008).
[6] The Churchâ€™s complaint and brief to this court set
  forth arguments such as, an absence of any meeting of the minds, a lack of the
  signatoriesâ€™ ability to bind the Church, forgery, and failure of the Church to
  approve the Contract, all of which deal with fraud in factum, i.e., ineffective
  assent to the Contract. Great Western Coal, 312 S.C. at 562, 437
S.E.2d at 24. 
[7] â€œDetermining whether a party agreed to arbitrate a
  particular dispute is an issue for judicial determination to be decided as a
  matter of contract.â€ Towles, 338 S.C. at 41, 524 S.E.2d at 846.Â  Whether
  a particular claim is subject to arbitration has been examined in many cases,
  including, Aiken, 373 S.C. 144, 644 S.E.2d 705; Chassereau, 373
  S.C. 168, 644 S.E.2d 718; Zabinski, 346 S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110; Timms
    v. Greene, 310 S.C. 469, 427 S.E.2d 642 (1993); Vestry & Church
      Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross v. Orkin Exterminating Co., 356
  S.C. 202, 588 S.E.2d 136 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This issue is not presently before
  the court.
[8] In Simpson v. MSA of
  Myrtle Beach, Inc., 373 S.C. 14, 644 S.E.2d 663 (2007), the South Carolina
  Supreme Court recently noted that severability is not always an appropriate
  remedy for an unconscionable provision in an arbitration clause especially in
  situations where â€œâ€˜illegality pervades the arbitration agreement such that only
  a disintegrated fragment would remain after hacking away the unenforceable
  parts.â€™â€ 373 S.C. at 34, 644 S.E.2d at 673.Â  This situation is not presently
  before us since the Church has made no claims regarding the unconscionability
  of its Contract with Paragon Builders.Â  The supreme court emphasized the
  importance of a case-by-case analysis to address unique circumstances
  surrounding the evaluation of an arbitration clause for unconscionability and
  further distinguished Simpson from cases such as the one sub judice by holding the arbitration clause in Simpson is unconscionable due to a
  multitude of one-sided terms.Â  Id. at 36, 644 S.E.2d at 674.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Ex Parte: Joe
          W. Kent, Appellant/Respondent.
        Leroy E. Capps
          and Harriette Capps, Respondents,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Transportation, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4434
  Submitted May 1, 2008 â€“ Filed August 28,
2008
Refiled October 6, 2008

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., and Carmen V.
          Ganjehsani, both of Columbia, for Appellant-Respondent.
        William P. Hatfield, of Florence, for
          Respondents.
        D. MalloyÂ  McEachin, of Florence, for
          Respondent-Appellants.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: In
  this case, the trial court granted a new trial and issued sanctions for contempt.Â 
  We affirm in part and reverse in part. 
FACTS
This
  case arises from a motor vehicle accident. A tractor trailer truck driven by
  Bobby Connor (Connor)[1] made a turn while on a detour road.Â  While making the turn, Connor traversed
  into the opposing lane of travel.Â  Leroy E. Capps and Harriette Capps
  (collectively the Capps) were traveling in the opposing lane when the tractor
  trailer collided with the Cappsâ€™ vehicle.Â  The Capps filed suit against Connor
  and the South Carolina Department of Transportation (the SCDOT).[2]
As a
  basis of their suit, the Capps alleged the SCDOT: (1) knowingly selected a
  route which could not safely accommodate tractor trailers because the tractor
  trailers would encroach into the opposing lane of travel; (2) failed to place
  advance warning signs alerting oncoming motorists of this danger; and (3)
  failed to modify the detour route to make it safer or failed to choose a safer
  alternative route.Â  
During
  the trial, the SCDOT attempted to assert Connorâ€™s superseding negligence as a
  defense.Â  In support of this defense, the SCDOT retained the services of Joe
  Kent (Kent).Â  Kent is an expert in accident reconstruction and highway
  engineering related to accidents.Â  Kent testified that an accident report was
  important in forming the foundation for his opinions.Â  
When asked what factors within the accident report he relied on in
  arriving at his conclusion, Kent responded, â€œThe orientation of the vehicles
  and the motion of the vehicles. . . . There was also an estimated speed . . .
  of 45 [MPH] for Mr. Capps and five [MPH] for Mr. Conner. . . . I also noted
  (sic) that from this report that Mr. Conner was cited for failure to yield
  right of way.â€Â  The Capps immediately moved for a mistrial, arguing evidence of
  whether Connor received a ticket was inadmissible.Â  The trial court denied the
  Cappsâ€™ motion for a mistrial but did issue a curative instruction to the jury.Â 
  Additionally, the trial court issued contempt sanctions in the amount of $1,500
  against Kent.Â  Initially, the trial court ordered Kent to pay this amount to
  the Florence County Humane Society.Â  Subsequently, the trial court determined
  that payment to the Humane Society did â€œnot further the ends of justiceâ€ and
  ordered payment be made to the Cappsâ€™ counsel.Â Â Â  
The jury returned a verdict in favor of the SCDOT.Â  The Capps
  moved for a new trial pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP, and separately under the
  thirteenth juror doctrine. The Capps specifically asked the trial court to
  reconsider its denial of the Cappsâ€™ motion for a mistrial.Â  The trial court
  granted the Cappsâ€™ motion for a new trial.Â  Kent and the SCDOT appeal the trial
  courtâ€™s rulings.Â  We address each partiesâ€™ argument in turn. 
A. Kentâ€™s
  appeal 
Kent argues the trial court committed reversible error when it issued contempt sanctions
  against him.Â  We agree.[3]Â  
The
  determination of contempt ordinarily rests within the sound discretion of the
  trial judge.Â  State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217
  (Ct. App. 1994).Â 
  Contempt is an extreme measure and the power to find an individual in contempt
  is not to be lightly asserted.Â  Id. at
  128, 447 S.E.2d at 216. Â Contempt results from the willful disobedience of a court order
  and before a person may be held in contempt, the record must be clear and
  specific as to acts or conduct upon which the contempt is based.Â  Id. at 129, 447 S.E.2d at 217. A willful act is an act â€œdone voluntarily and
  intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with
  the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that
  is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€Â  Id. (internal quotations omitted).Â  If the primary purpose of the sanctions imposed
  is to preserve the courtâ€™s authority and to punish for disobedience of its
  orders, the contempt is considered criminal.Â  Id. at 128, 447 S.E.2d at
  217.Â  Conversely, if the purpose of the sanctions is to coerce obedience to a
  court order, the contempt is civil.Â  Id. at 129, 447 S.E.2d at 217.
In the
  instant case, the trial court issued contempt sanctions upon Kent on the basis that Kent deliberately gave inadmissible testimony in the form of Connorâ€™s
  citation.Â  In issuing contempt sanctions, the trial court reasoned that Kent had substantial and continuous involvement in court proceedings as an expert witness
  over a number of years and should have known that evidence regarding a citation
  was inadmissible.Â  The following colloquy during the trial indicates the trial
  court made no inquiry to determine Kentâ€™s knowledge regarding the admissibility
  or inadmissibility of a citation.Â  

  Q: Did you . . . review . . . the accident
    report in regard to this case? 
  [Kent]: I did. 
  Q: Did that . . . have any significance to
    you in your evaluation?Â  
  A: It does.Â  It has basically a description
    of the vehicles.Â  It has a description of the motions of the vehicles and also
    it helps clarify the pictures of the accident scene taken by the State Patrol
    right after that accident that I reviewed.Â  And it reveals in the narrative
    portion--
  [Counsel for the Capps]: Iâ€™m going to
    object.Â  Thatâ€™s hearsay, if your honor please.
  [Counsel for the SCDOT]: Your honor, may I
    respond now?
  The Court: Yes, sir.
  [Counsel for the SCDOT]: Let me get the
    rule out but under the rule an expert is entitled to rely on hearsay.
  The Court: There is a distinction between
    relying on it and publishing it counsel. 
  [Counsel for the Capps]: Plus thereâ€™s a
    specific statute.
  The Court: What says [sic] you? What say
    you to that?
  [Counsel for the SCDOT]: Your honor I think
    he would be entitled to testify if he had figures regarding speed for
    instance.Â  I think he would be able to rely on that and say thatâ€™s what he
    relied on in regard to â€“ to a speed.Â  I think he would be able to testify as to
    how he arrived at his opinion just as the plaintiffâ€™s expert testified relying
    on hearsay.
  The Court: All right. Counsel, Iâ€™m going
    to overrule your objection and allow that.Â  Again the basis of his
    opinion is for the jury to determine whether or not that opinion is credible or
    believable.Â  The court will allow that.Â  You may proceed [Counsel for the
    SCDOT].
  [Counsel for the SCDOT]: Thank you, your
    honor.
  Q: In . . . examining the accident report
    were there factors that you relied on in arriving at your conclusion in this
    case?
  A: There were.
  Q: All right, sir. And . . . what were
    those? 
  A: The orientation of the vehicles and the
    motion of the vehicles as described in the narrative portion and as shown in
    the diagram.Â  There also was an estimated speed listed by the investigating
    officer of 45 miles per hour for Mr. Capps and fives miles an hour for Mr.
    Conner who was driving the tractor trailer who pulled out onto Highway 51.Â  I
    also noted that â€“ from this report that Mr. Conner was cited for failure to
    yield right of way. 

(emphasis added)
Based
  upon the testimony at trial and the evidence in the record, we find there is
  not sufficient evidence to suggest that Kent, in fact, knew the testimony was
  inadmissible or that he willfully disobeyed a court order.Â  See Curlee
    v. Howle, 277 S.C. 377, 382, 287 S.E.2d 915, 918 (1982) (â€œContempt results
  from the willful disobedience of an order of the court, and before a person may
  be held in contempt, the record must be clear and specific as to the acts or
  conduct upon which such finding is based.â€); see also State v.
    Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 571-72, 611 S.E.2d 273, 275 (Ct. App. 2005)
  (applying the requirement of willfulness in the context of criminal contempt).Â  Â Furthermore, there was no court order
  forbidding Kentâ€™s testimony.Â  In fact, the trial court allowed Kent to testify after overruling the Cappsâ€™ objection regarding Kentâ€™s ability to rely on the narrative portion of the accident
  report.Â  Kent was not asked a question to which there was a sustained objection
  and thereafter answered without a ruling from the trial court.Â  Rather, the
  trial court overruled the objection and allowed Kent to testify. Â 
While we are mindful of the trial courtâ€™s concern and recognize
  the possibility of such knowledge of inadmissible evidence by an individual who
  regularly appears in court, we nonetheless find the extent of such knowledge
  for the purposes of determining willfulness must be sufficiently established by
  the record prior to an imposition of a contempt sanction.Â  Â The extent of Kentâ€™s knowledge was not established in
  the record and may not be established by speculation.Â  Accordingly, we must
